awd_titl_txt: AMPS:   Collaborative Research:   Stochastic Modeling of the Power Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop mathematical models for the interactions between the economic stake-holders in the modern power grid. While the electricity market is becoming decentralized, understanding the underlying market forces in the presence of fluctuating market conditions and regulations remains inadequate. Providing higher quality information and modeling aids to decision makers is crucial in the drive to achieve grid efficiency and enhanced stability. It is also central to avoiding unintended consequences that have plagued economic policy-making for the grid and for making effective regulations that incentivize aligning stakeholder behavior with societal goals, such as climate change adaptation and investment in new technologies.

The project will construct rigorous stochastic models and related numerical algorithms for quantitative assessment and analysis of how to guide the grid in its "smart" evolution.  The research will address (i) long-term grid evolution, in particular investment in renewable generation and competition between different producer sectors; (ii) behavior of electricity prices and related financial contracts in the new era of deep renewable penetration, micro-grids, and new requirements on grid stability. The project blends together applied mathematics, game theory, and control, and extends the reach of stochastics to a key application area. The project will contribute to inter-disciplinary training in mathematical sciences at the PhD level and will enhance the exchange of ideas between mathematicians, operations researchers, engineers, and statisticians.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Reliance on renewable resources for real-time and spontaneous demand in energy often fails due to
changes in weather patterns. For example, on a cloudy day, it is difficult for solar panels to function
efficiently. Furthermore, there are currently no long term solutions to storing the energy produced
on very sunny days to insure against those cloudy ones. As a result, most energy produced is used
immediately and planning for future production brings much uncertainty. This hinders the current
market design in place to reliably deliver electricity across the energy grid. The
complexity added by the growth in energy generators of renewable resource, along with the increase
of policies that mandate these generators be a substantial part of production leads to instability in
the energy grid. Currently, the market that sets the price for electricity in the northeast operates
under the expectation that generators commit to produce an energy target prior to the moment
when the electricity is needed. If generators fail to reach these targets then the market operators
must scramble to find the excess capacity to fill in the gap. These scenarios are sure to arise more
frequently as the penetration of renewable energy generators continues to increase. To mitigate the
effect and maybe even reduce the chance of these scenarios, market operators have experimented
with penalties on the generators to encourage them to commit to an achievable target. The goal
of this research is to explore the commitment decisions of renewable firms competing against
the more reliable conventional firms (coal, natural gas, etc). The models proposed are static games
with multiple profit-maximizing firms choosing a production quantity based on an uncertain demand
curve such as in the day-ahead electricity market. The
model accurately depicts the bidding behavior of the day-ahead market by using a supply function
equilibrium. In addition, by exploring actual bidding behavior in the day-ahead market, we
provide evidence to the hypothesis that renewable firms may be under-committing their generation
offers in the market. The analysis is completed by using soft clustering to identify renewable
generators. This report presents a formal model to describe the bidding behavior and decision of generators in
the day-ahead energy market. The model retains the complexities
of interactions between generators in the midst of simultaneous sources of uncertainty. The report
also shows some preliminary evidence that renewable generators do indeed under-forecast when they
bid. However it is not clear whether this is a strategic decision or due to their forecasting capabilities.


Last Modified: 05/08/2022
Modified by: K. Ronnie Sircar

Image

    Self
    Public Domain
    K. Ronnie Sircar
    Bids
